Technical Assistance Report 
Project Number: 47051 
Project Preparatory Technical Assistance 
June 2013 
 
 
 
 
People’s Republic of China: Chemical Industry 
Energy Efficiency and Emission Reduction Project 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  A project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) of $700,000 is required to prepare the 
project. The PPTA will be implemented in two parts. During Part 1 of the PPTA, an innovative 
energy service company (ESCO) financing structure will be developed in close cooperation 
between  the  China  National  Chemical  Corporation  (ChemChina),  China  Haohua  Chemical 
Group Co., Ltd. (CHC), potential ESCOs, the National Development and Reform Commission 
(NDRC), financial intermediaries, and other stakeholders. Together with the financing structure, 
the overall ensuing loan implementation arrangements will also  be firmed up. Due to potential 
environmental impacts,  an in-depth energy audit and environmental impact assessment (EIA) 
of the subprojects will be conducted in parallel to the development of the financing structure 
during the part 1 of the PPTA.  
 
2.  The  part 2 of the PPTA  will (i) conduct technical, economic and financial due diligence 
of subprojects; (ii) strengthen the implementing agency in Asian Development Bank’s (ADB’s) 
guidelines on procurement and loan disbursement; and (iii) carry out necessary assessments of 
the executing and implementing agencies, including financial management and procurement 
capacity  assessments.  Further  analysis  and  consulting  services  requirements  will  be 
determined at the end of the PPTA’s part 1.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
4.  The PPTA is estimated to cost $850,000 equivalent, of which $700,000 equivalent will 
be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other 
sources). The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation, secretarial assistance, local transportation, provision of office space, access to 
the sites, studies, report and other information relevant to financing the subprojects, and other 
in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimate is presented in Table A4.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
5.  The PPTA will be implemented in two parts. Part 1 will focus on the (i) development of 
an innovative ESCO financing mechanism, and (ii) energy audit and environmental impact 
assessment  (EIA).  A  review  of  ChemChina  and  chemical  industry  energy  efficiency  and 
emission reduction market assessment and barrier analysis will also be undertaken during part 
1. Since these activities are independent activities, four individual consultants (2 international for 
a total of 6.5 person-months and 2 national for a total of 7 person-months) will be recruited in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time). The energy efficiency finance experts will work closely with ChemChina, NDRC, and ADB 
to develop the financing mechanism. The international environment expert will be supported by 
a national technical expert to prepare the energy audit and the EIA.  
 
6.  Part  2  will  be  undertaken  by  a  consulting  firm,  which  will  prepare  the  technical, 
economic, and financial due diligence of the subprojects to be undertaken. It will also provide 
capacity strengthening and project implementation support and capacity development measures 
to the project management office and other stakeholders, if needed. The detailed tasks to be 
undertaken by the consulting firm will be firmed up towards the end of the part 1. The consulting 
firm will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time) through quality- and cost-based selection method (with a quality-
cost ratio of 80:20) following the simplified technical proposal.

7.  The outline terms of reference for the PPTA consultants are described in paras. 8 to 15.  
 
1.  Part 1 of Project Preparatory Technical Assistance   
 
8.  Energy efficiency finance expert (international, 2.5 person-months intermittent). The 
expert should have broad international experience in structuring energy efficiency financing 
transactions  using  credit  enhancements  and  other  instruments.  The  expert  should  have  a 
postgraduate degree in finance or another relevant degree and should have at least 5 years of

4 
 
relevant experiences in ESCO financing. The expert will have to work closely together with the 
executing agency, NDRC, and ADB for the development of the financing mechanism. The tasks 
to be undertaken by the expert include: 
(i)  Review lessons learned from previous projects of ADB and other multilateral and 
bilateral development organizations to foster energy efficiency financing in the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC). 
(ii)  Capture lessons learned from (a) innovative ESCO financing in the European 
Union and the United States, and (b) ESCO models by other large energy groups 
in the PRC. 
(iii)  Assess  key  barriers  to  financing  industrial  energy  efficiency  projects  in 
ChemChina and CHC using structured interviews to be undertaken by national 
consultants. 
(iv)  Building up on the lessons learned in Europe, the PRC and the United States, 
advise on the detailed governance issues for a newly established ESCO owned 
 
by CHC.
(v)  Establish the criteria for choosing ESCO and capacity requirements for ESCO to 
 
sustainably access the financing mechanism. 
(vi)  Review the existing incentive and policy regime for promoting energy efficiency 
and emission reduction investments in the chemical industry and identify any 
additional  incentives  required  to  improve  the  investment  climate  for  energy 
 
efficiency investments in the chemical industry.
(vii)  Based on the findings, propose a multi-pronged ESCO financing mechanism 
leveraging  the  proposed  ADB  loan  to  mobilize  additional  financing  from 
commercial  banks,  equity  funding,  and  other  sources  to  upscale  energy 
efficiency financing. This includes defining a strategy and structure to leverage 
ADB funds with (a) commercial cofinancing from domestic financial institutions, 
(b)  a  structured  ESCO  fund  with  or  without  ADB  participation,  and/or  (c)  a 
 
guarantee fund with or without ADB participation.
(viii)  Determine the most appropriate ADB loan modality to finance energy efficiency 
 
projects.
(ix)  Selecting  appropriate  financial  intermediary  and  ESCO  for  implementing  the 
financing mechanism and design capacity development program, including (a) 
establishing selection criteria, (b) designing the selection process, (c) evaluating 
proposals,  and  (d)  assessing financial  management capacity  of the financial 
intermediary and ESCO.  
 
(x)  Establish a workplan for implementing the proposed financing structure.
(xi)  Elaborate report on the (a) key findings of energy efficiency financing review, (b) 
rationale and sustainability for the proposed financing mechanism, (c) proposed 
ADB loan modality. 
(xii)  Incorporate comments and feedbacks from ADB in the report. 
(xiii)  Contribute to a knowledge sharing event on leveraging concessionary energy 
efficiency funding to foster ESCO funding in energy-intensive industries. 
 
9.  Environment expert (international, 4 person-months, intermittent). The expert should 
have a postgraduate degree in environmental science, environmental engineering, chemical 
engineering, chemistry or relevant field, and at least 10 years of relevant working experiences. 
The  expert  must  have  at  least  3  years  environmental  auditing  experience,  including 
environmental auditing for chemical industry. A certified environmental auditor is desirable.  The 
expert  will  organize the  work  and  in  conjunction  with the  national technical  expert  will  be 
responsible for the following activities: 
(i)  Visit all the subproject sites.

5 
 
(ii)  Review the overall operations of the facilities and their environment and safety 
management systems.  
(iii)  Gather data using questionnaires on-site inspections, relevant document reviews 
and interviews. 
(iv)  Examine  the  records  for  appropriate  government  permits,  requirements, 
environment  and  safety  standards,  and  maintenance  and  inventory  control 
measures. 
(v)  Assess the status of environment and social compliance status, including any 
safeguards  concerns  related  to  the  impacts  on  the  environment,  involuntary 
resettlement and indigenous peoples. 
(vi)  Review  environment,  health  and  safety  management  systems,  emergency 
preparedness  and  response  procedures,  employee  training,  environmental 
monitoring  programs, chemicals  and  hazardous  chemicals  management,  and 
waste management efforts. 
(vii)  If non-compliance and any other environmental, health and safety concerns are 
raised, propose corrective actions.  
(viii)  Review relevant documents, including domestic EIA reports that were prepared 
by  local  EIA  institutes  and  feasibility  study  reports  for  ADB-financed  project 
components.  
(ix)  Identify information gaps to assess environmental impacts of the ADB-financed 
product  components,  collect  sufficient  information  through  primary  and 
secondary data collection to evaluate environmental impacts of the project, and 
identify environmental risks.  
(x)  Review planned mitigation measures for ADB-financed project components and 
propose,  if  needed,  additional  environmental  mitigation  measures  and 
recommend environmentally-friendly technologies particularly for the design and 
construction. 
(xi)  Establish environmental baseline indicators and performance targets.  
(xii)  Assess and quantify, in conjunction with the technical expert, the environment 
benefits  such  as  energy  savings,  emission  reduction,  and  other  associated 
environmental benefits. 
(xiii)  Answer  any  specific  safeguards  related  questions  regarding  the  polyvinyl 
chloride and caustic soda production chains ADB might have.  
(xiv)  Assist  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  to  prepare  an  initial 
environmental examination, including the environment management plan (EMP) 
for ADB-financed product components.   
(xv)  Carry  out  cost  review  of  the  proposed  environmental  mitigation  measures 
indicated in the EMP for ADB-financed product components, and prepare a list of 
activities and budget requirements for independent environment monitoring and 
evaluation during project implementation.  
(xvi)  Prepare  a  consolidated  English  environmental  audit  report  for  the  two 
subprojects, including the EMP for ADB-financed product components, which can 
meet all the ADB safeguard requirements in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard 
Policy Statement (2009). 
(xvii)  Incorporate comments and feedbacks from ADB in regards to the environmental 
audit report. 
 
10.  If the project becomes a financial intermediation loan project with the characteristics of 
sector loan, the environment expert also will be responsible for the following activities: 
(i)  Prepare an environmental assessment and review framework (EARF) to provide 
guidance on screening and categorization, assessment, planning, institutional

6 
 
arrangements, and processes to be followed for other future subprojects under 
the loan. EARF must meet the ADB requirements in accordance with ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement.  
(ii)  Undertake  an  in-depth  assessment  of  its  current  ESMS  of  the  financial 
intermediary for the project and identify areas where improvements are needed. 
The  ESMS  assessment  shall  focus  on  the  financial  intermediary’s  (a) 
environmental and social policies; (b) safeguard screening, categorization, and 
review  procedures;  (c)  current  organization  structure  and  staffing;  (d) 
performance  monitoring  and  reporting  procedures;  and  (v)  track  record  in 
environmental and social management. 
(iii)  If  the  financial  intermediary  does  not  have  an  ESMS,  assist  the  financial 
intermediary’s to develop and establish an ESMS appropriate to the level of 
potential environmental and social impacts and risks. The ESMS shall include the 
provision that all other subprojects under FI meet ADB’s requirements specified 
in the ADB safeguard requirements in addition to national laws and standards. 
 
11.  Technical expert (national, 4.0 person-months, intermittent). The expert should have a 
postgraduate  degree  in  chemical  engineering,  chemistry,  environmental  management  or 
relevant field, and at least 5 years of working experience. The expert must be fluent in English 
and Chinese. The expert will undertake the following activities:  
(i)  Visit all the project sites. 
(ii)  Assist  the  environment  expert  in  reviewing  the  overall  operations  and 
environment and safety management systems. 
(iii)  Support  the  environment  expert  in  data  collection  by  reviewing  relevant 
documents, preparing questionnaires in Chinese, and conducting interviews.   
(iv)  Assist  the  environment  expert  in  performing  management  performance  and 
safeguards compliance audits. 
(v)  Support  the  international  environment  expert  in  assessing  the  technologies’ 
potential in improving the energy efficiency and emission reduction.  
(vi)  Review domestic EIA reports and translate them into English.  
(vii)  Support  the  environment  expert  in  identifying  information  gaps,  collecting 
sufficient information through primary and secondary data collection, performing 
a  preliminary  assessment  of  the  environmental  benefits,  energy  efficiency 
improvements, pollution reductions, and other environmental benefits.  
(viii)  Support  the  international  environment  expert  in  preparing  the  technology 
alternative analysis, preparing the cost estimation of environmental mitigation 
measures and implementation of the environmental monitoring plan. 
(ix)  Support  the  international  environment  expert  in  answering  any  specific 
safeguards related questions regarding the polyvinyl chloride and caustic soda 
production chains ADB might have.  
(x)  Depending on the chosen loan modality, support the international environmental 
expert in preparing the EARF and the ESMS. 
(xi)  Support  the  international  environment  expert  in  reviewing  any  legacy  issues 
regarding the health and safety of workers and nearby communities.  
(xii)  Provide communication facilitation among ADB, the executing and implementing 
agencies, other local government officers, and other relevant people engaged in 
the project, who might need English-Chinese translations. 
 
12.  Energy  efficiency  finance  expert  (national,  3.0  person-months,  intermittent).  The 
expert should have a postgraduate degree in finance, economics or another related field. The 
expert should have at least 5 years of relevant work experiences, and ideally would have

7 
 
previously worked with an international financing institution in establishing an ESCO financing 
mechanism  for  energy  efficiency  projects.  The  expert  should  further  have  experiences  in 
financial  due  diligence  and  financial  management  assessment  procedures  of  financial 
intermediaries. The detailed tasks will include: 
(i)  Support the international expert in capturing lessons learned from (a) previous 
efforts by multinational and bilateral development organizations to foster ESCO 
financing in the PRC, and (b) state-of-the art ESCO financing mechanisms in the 
European Union and the United States. 
(ii)  Support the international energy efficiency finance expert in data collection by 
reviewing  relevant  documents,  preparing  questionnaires  in  Chinese,  and 
conducting interviews with financial institutes, commercial banks, and ESCOs.  
(iii)  Evaluate the organizational structure and summarize the financial management 
and  control  systems  of  potential  participating  ESCOs  and  possible  oversight 
exercised by the executing agency.  
(iv)  Support  the  international  energy  efficiency  finance  expert  in  developing  an 
innovative  ESCO  financing  mechanism  adapted  to  the  current  constraints  for 
financing industrial energy efficiency retrofits. 
(v)  Support the international energy efficiency finance expert in (a) defining criteria for 
selecting  the  financial  intermediary  and  ESCO  in  consultation  with  ADB,  (b) 
designing  the  selection  process  for  financial  intermediary  and  ESCO,  and  (c) 
selecting the entities based on the selection criteria prepared. 
(vi)  Undertake  a  thorough  financial  management  assessment  of  selected  financial 
intermediary and ESCO in accordance with ADB’s guidelines (2005).1 
(vii)  Assess the financial sustainability of the financing mechanism.  
(viii)  Propose  auditing  and  accounting  procedures  and  financial  management 
procedures in accordance with ADB’s fiduciary requirements and Anticorruption 
Policy (1998, as amended to date).  
(ix)  Support the international energy efficiency finance expert in elaborating the report.  
(x)  Depending  on the firmed  up  loan modality,  prepare  capacity  building  plan for 
financial intermediary and the selected ESCO. 
 
2.  Part 2 of Project Preparatory Technical Assistance   
 
13.  Part 2 will be conducted by a consulting firm. As mentioned in para. 6, the required types 
of experts, detailed terms of reference, and consultants’ selection methods will be firmed up 
while part 1 of the PPTA is being implemented.   
 
E.  Reporting Requirements 
 
14.  The consultants shall submit (i) an inception report within 1 month after signing the 
consulting  contract;  (ii)  two  draft  final  reports,  one  documenting  the  innovative  financing 
structure (month 3) and the other document the environmental assessments (month 4); and (iii) 
a final report within 1 month after receiving feedback from ADB on the draft final report. 
 
15.  All  PPTA  deliverables  and  progress  reports  will  be  written  in  English.  National 
consultants will be responsible for translating documents into Chinese. Three copies of each 
technical assistance (TA) deliverable will be submitted to ADB in English, and four copies will be 
submitted to ChemChina, one in English and three in Chinese. The deliverables and progress 
reports should address the terms of reference with details appropriate to that stage of the TA. 
The consultants will present key findings in workshops and seminars. Officials from the Ministry 
of Finance, NDRC, and ChemChina will be consultated in the preparation of the reports.

8 
 
 
F.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  ChemChina, will be the executing agency. It will set up a steering committee together 
with the China Haohua Chemical Group Co. Ltd, a subgroup under ChemChina and owner of 
the industries Dezhou Shihua Chemical Co., Ltd., and Haohua Yuhang Chemical Co., Ltd. The 
steering committee will (i) work with the consultants in part 1 for the establishment of the 
innovative ESCO financing mechanism, and (ii) provide strategic advice during the PPTA and 
the implementation period of ensuing loan. Dezhou Shihua Chemical Co., Ltd., and Haohua 
Yuhang Chemical Co., Ltd. will act as implementing agencies and will provide counterpart staff, 
office  space  and  necessary  data  and  information  about  energy  efficiency  and  emission 
reduction industry in the chemical industry.  
 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 15 months from 15 June 2013, with an expected 
completion date of 15 September 2014.  The proposed TA processing and implementation 
schedule is listed in Table A4.4.
